intro: Mentha × gayeri, commonly known as catnip, is a hybrid mint species belonging to the Lamiaceae family. It is characterized by its square, erect stems and opposite, ovate to lanceolate leaves that are often covered in fine hairs. The plant produces small, pale blue or purple flowers in whorled clusters, which bloom during the summer months. Mentha × gayeri is native to Europe and parts of Asia, and it thrives in moist, well-drained soils. It is widely cultivated for its aromatic properties and has a long history of use in traditional medicine and as a natural insect repellent.
